title: AB 2687
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 23152 of the Vehicle Code in California prohibits driving under the influence of alcohol. It is illegal to drive with a blood alcohol concentration of 0.08% or higher. Blood alcohol concentration is measured in grams of alcohol per 100 milliliters of blood or grams of alcohol per 210 liters of breath. It is illegal to drive with a blood alcohol concentration of 0.08% or higher. This is based on grams of alcohol per 100 milliliters of blood or grams of alcohol per 210 liters of breath. In any prosecution, it is presumed that a person had 0.08% or more alcohol in their blood at the time of driving if a chemical test within three hours after driving shows this level. In any prosecution, it is presumed that a person had 0.08% or more alcohol in their blood at the time of driving if a chemical test within three hours after driving shows this level. It is also unlawful for a person addicted to drugs to drive, except for those in an approved narcotic treatment program. It is illegal to drive a commercial motor vehicle with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood. If a chemical test within three hours after driving shows this level, it is presumed that the person had 0.04% or more alcohol in their blood at the time of driving. Starting July 1, 2018, it is illegal to drive a motor vehicle with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood when a passenger for hire is present. A passenger for hire is someone who pays or is expected to pay for the ride. If caught, there is a presumption that the driver had 0.04% or more alcohol in their blood at the time of driving. In a prosecution, there is a rebuttable presumption that the person had 0.04% or more alcohol in their blood at the time of driving if a chemical test within three hours after driving shows the same. It is illegal to drive under the influence of drugs or a combination of alcohol and drugs. Section 23153 of the Vehicle Code prohibits driving under the influence of alcohol, leading to bodily injury to others. Section 23153 of the Vehicle Code prohibits driving under the influence of alcohol, with a blood alcohol level of 0.08% or more, leading to bodily injury to others. It is illegal to drive with a blood alcohol level of 0.08% or more and cause bodily injury to someone else. If a chemical test within three hours after driving shows a blood alcohol level of 0.08% or more, it is presumed that the person had that level at the time of driving. In a prosecution, it is presumed that a person had 0.08% or more alcohol in their blood at the time of driving if a chemical test within three hours after driving shows the same level. It is not necessary to prove a specific violation of the law to establish negligence in driving. It is illegal to drive a commercial vehicle with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood, causing bodily injury to others. Presumed if 0.04% or more alcohol is detected within three hours after driving. It is unlawful to drive a motor vehicle with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood if a passenger for hire is present and causes bodily injury to another person. In cases where a passenger for hire is present, it is illegal to drive a vehicle with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood, leading to bodily injury to someone other than the driver. A rebuttable presumption exists if the person had 0.04% or more alcohol in their blood within three hours after driving. It is illegal to drive a vehicle under the influence of any drug or a combination of alcohol and drugs, leading to bodily injury to someone other than the driver. No reimbursement is required by this act as it creates a new crime or infraction, eliminates a crime or infraction, or changes penalties, as defined by the Government Code and California Constitution.
